content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

From the thumbnail, I see three main pieces of tissue that have the characteristic ovoid shape and dense, purple cellularity of lymph nodes. They are embedded in pale, wispy connective and adipose tissue. The lymph nodes appear very cellular and 'busy', which could indicate either a reactive process or metastatic involvement. My initial goal would be to systematically examine each of these nodes for evidence of cancer.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this specific area because it is located at the periphery of the leftmost and largest lymph node. Tumor cells from a primary colorectal cancer typically travel through lymphatic vessels and first deposit in the subcapsular sinus of a lymph node. Therefore, the periphery, just under the capsule, is the most critical area to examine for early metastatic deposits. This represents a systematic approach to screening the lymph node for positivity. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist evaluating lymph nodes for colorectal cancer staging, the primary goal is to identify metastatic tumor cells. I am systematically examining all the lymph nodes provided. I chose to zoom into this specific area of the rightmost lymph node because it appears architecturally distorted and has prominent dark, discolored patches on the low-power view. Any area that deviates from the normal, homogeneous appearance of a lymph node is a prime target for investigation, as it could represent metastasis, necrosis, or other significant pathology. This is the most abnormal-looking area on the slide. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would zoom into this area because it represents one of the potential lymph nodes that needs to be examined. This is the second and smallest of the three main lymph node-like structures from the left. It is standard practice to systematically evaluate every piece of tissue submitted as a lymph node at high magnification to definitively rule in or rule out the presence of metastatic tumor cells, regardless of the node's size or low-power appearance. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I can see the capsule of the lymph node at the top, with perinodal adipose tissue. Below the capsule is the subcapsular sinus, which appears to be expanded and filled with small, dark, round cells consistent with lymphocytes. The bulk of the image shows a dense population of lymphocytes, which make up the cortex of the node. There are also scattered deposits of black granular material, which is anthracotic pigment (carbon), a common and benign finding. I do not see any definitive nests of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or large cells with prominent nucleoli that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is that of a reactive lymph node with sinus lymphocytosis and anthracosis. There is no evidence of metastasis in this particular view.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see lymph node parenchyma. The most prominent feature is the massive deposition of coarse, black, irregular pigment. This pigment is located within the sinuses and is engulfed by macrophages (histiocytes). This finding is characteristic of anthracosis (carbon pigment), and the expansion of the sinuses by these pigment-laden macrophages is termed sinus histiocytosis. The surrounding lymphoid tissue appears reactive. Crucially, I do not see any definitive nests of atypical epithelial cells or malignant glands that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is marked anthracosis and reactive sinus histiocytosis, which is a benign finding. However, I would need to carefully examine the entire lymph node to ensure that metastatic cells are not being obscured by the heavy pigment.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the architecture of a lymph node. There are follicles composed of dense populations of small, round lymphocytes. A striking feature is the presence of abundant, coarse, black granular pigment, which is consistent with anthracosis (carbon pigment). This pigment is located within macrophages in the sinuses (sinus histiocytosis with anthracosis). The overall architecture is preserved, and I do not see any atypical glandular structures, clusters of malignant cells, or features of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node with prominent anthracosis, and there is no evidence of metastasis in this field of view.
